Description: Limestone stela of Hatia: a round-topped stela divided into three registers with figures in sunk relief and incised texts. In the upper register Hatia on the right pours a libation over an altar heaped with offerings. Behind it Osiris is enthroned in the centre of the register. Isis and Horus stand behind him. In the second register the lady May is seated on the left behind an altar piled with offerings. Hatia pours a libation over this altar accompanied by the lady Satiry. Ptahpay and the lady Ber are seated on the right behind an altar heaped with offerings. In the third register Pashedy is seated on the left behind an altar covered with offerings over which a libation is poured by Sethmose followed by the lady Baketamun. On the right sits the lady Tamekhit, to whom offerings are being made by the lady Hotep and Amenemheb. The stela is much damaged and worn along the edges and corners. It is discoloured by brown stains and is suffering badly from salt which is lifting the surface in places.
Curator's comments: Bibliography: The British Museum, 'A guide to the Egyptian galleries (Sculpture)' (London, 1909), 201 (no. 730).
Bibliographic references: Bierbrier 1993 / Hieroglyphic texts from Egyptian stelae, etc., in the British Museum, Part 12. (Pl.100-101)
Condition: The stela is much damaged and worn along the edges and corners. It is discoloured by brown stains and is suffering badly from salt which is lifting the surface in places.
